column4: how come i have a folder with 777 permissions yet when i try to open it with nautilus it says 'access was denied'?
you don't own it. 'sudo chown <yourusername> folder'
i own the file and with 777 permissions yet nautilus cant open it. i can cd into it though.
go to the directory where the file is and run 'ls -l <file>' and paste the result here.
it is a folder. i can cd into it, however nautilus can't open it.
ls -l <folder>
^ from ls -l
everything should work. It must be something with nautilus.
I use KDE so I can't help you further. Sorry.
why would it pick on just this little folder?
hell if I know. Are there any unusual circumstances surrounding it?
i will just copy its contents into a new folder using the terminal
omg Nautilus boycotted by "Visual Communication" folder again!!!
rename it to something with a short name with no space. i.e. in the command line, execute 'mv Visual\ Communication foobar'
calling it foobar fixed it :S that didnt work last time
yes. "sudo chmod -R <code> ."
wait.
if i give everything permissions 700 it asks if i want to open or execute every file, if i give them permissions 600 i cant open any folders, so i need folders to have 700 and files to have 600.
list=`file * | grep directory | awk '{ print $1 }' | sed 's/://g'` && sudo chmod 700 $list
lol has do be done recursively tho
the command I gave you will do it.
to make it run for files only, replace "grep" with "grep -v"
okay i will try
